description.plain:
Kid Cudi, born Scott Ramon Seguro Mescudi on January 30, 1984, is an American recording artist from Cleveland, Ohio.

His debut single “Day ‘n’ Nite” became an online favorite in 2008. Based in Brooklyn, he first became affiliated with Fool’s Gold, the label of DJs A-Trak and Nick Catchdubs. After releasing his popular mixtape A Kid Named Cudi, Cudi’s career took off as he got associated with Kanye West and joined his label G.O.O.D Music.

His catalog currently counts 6 solo studio albums, entitled: Man on the Moon: The End of Day, Man on the Moon II: The Legend of Mr. Rager, Indicud which was released after Cudi famously departed from GOOD Music and the latest ones Satellite Flight: The Journey To Mother Moon, Speedin' Bullet To Heaven and Passion, Pain & Demon Slayin'.

In addition, Cudi released an alternative rock album with long-time friend and collaborator Dot Da Genius in duo group WZRD, as well as a collaborative album with on-again-off-again friend Kanye West as duo group Kids See Ghosts. Cudi has also been featured on the G.O.O.D Music projects: Cruel Summer and G.O.O.D. Fridays.

songs.title_with_featured: Just What I Am (Ft. King Chip)

description.plain:
Released October 2, 2012, this was the first track released off of Kid Cudi’s studio album, Indicud. The song is produced by Cudi himself.

The title is an allusion to Exodus 3:14 where God tells Moses “I am who I am.” This connection is draw upon throughout the song. Cudi and Chip use the phrase as a justification for their weed use: they love to get high, but that’s just who they are, and since God made them this way, there can be nothing wrong.

In 2016 “Just What I Am” was certified Platinum.

songs.title: Pursuit of Happiness (Nightmare)

description.plain:
Released as the third single from Kid Cudi’s debut album, Man on the Moon: The End of Day.

In his collaboration with MGMT and Ratatat, Kid Cudi discusses the lowlights of fame and fortune as well as the problems that haunted him following his father’s death.

It is the first track in the “nightmare” section of the album, as it leaves behind the album’s “dream” section.

songs.title: Day ‘N’ Nite (Nightmare)

description.plain:
Cudi’s first ever single, released in 2008, and to date his biggest track. It reached #3 on the US Billboard Charts and has sold over 5 million copies in the US.

Cudi said of the track:

My uncle that I lived with passed in 2006. We were actually beefing because he forced me out the house when I didn’t have another situation set up, so I was bitter. I never apologized for it, and that kills me. That’s why I wrote ‘Day ’N’ Nite.’

The track serves as Cudi’s justification for this “beef” with his deceased uncle, and the way he deals with the pain of their unresolved issues. The drugs help him “run,” but it’s the madness of the industry and making it that caused the problems in the first place.

In a 2012 interview with Complex, Cudi also disclosed:

A lot of people don’t know this but Geto Boys‘ ‘My Mind Playing Tricks On Me’ is the song that inspired 'Day 'N’ Nite.‘ 'My Mind Playing Tricks On Me’ is my favorite song in the world. I love it so much I wanted to make my own version of it. And then ‘Day 'N’ Nite' came out of it.

The track was remixed heavily, most notably by Crookers, and 3 separate music videos were shot, one for the original song and two for the Crookers remix.

The track first appeared on Cudi’s mixtape A Kid Named Cudi and then as “Day ‘N’ Nite (Nightmare)” on his debut album, Man on the Moon: The End of Day.

Producer Dot Da Genius broke down the making of “Day ‘N’ Nite” with Genius.

songs.title: Mr. Rager

description.plain:
https://twitter.com/ducidni/status/388093858808344576
A ballad for Mr. Rager, Cudi’s impulsive persona and the title character of his second album, Man on the Moon II: The Legend of Mr. Rager.

I think the New York Times has a pretty interesting take on this song:

In “Mr. Rager” he imagines himself as a role model telling kids about his adventures… as Kid Cudi sings, “I’m on my way to heaven” — not saying whether it’s via rapture or death.

The meaning of this song, particularly the music video, has been highly debated. However, most can agree there are two different Cudi’s in the video.

   View 1: Mr. Rager is the Cudi in black (the addicted one), and he destroys what’s left of the old Cudi, and the persona of Mr. Rager lives on.

   View 2: Mr. Rager is the Cudi in brown. The building is his body/life, which has been almost destroyed by himself and drugs. Mr. Rager, the addicted Cudi, is attempting to break back into his life again, which the new Cudi (black jacket) has recently regained control of (he was clean of coke when writing Mr. Rager). The people Mr. Rager fights are actually his friends (including Ye at 4:20) who are trying to help him (notice how none of them actually fight back, they just try to restrain him), but Mr. Rager fights against their help (as many drug addicts do). The 1 girl is in fact Jaime and the dust is a simple metaphor for the past (as she left him because of his poor decisions and drug abuse). In the end, only Cudi himself, can vanquish his own addiction and own self (Mr. Rager).

album.name: Man on the Moon II: The Legend of Mr. Rager

body.plain:
https://twitter.com/ducidni/status/388093858808344576
A ballad for Mr. Rager, Cudi’s impulsive persona and the title character of his second album, Man on the Moon II: The Legend of Mr. Rager.

I think the New York Times has a pretty interesting take on this song:

In “Mr. Rager” he imagines himself as a role model telling kids about his adventures… as Kid Cudi sings, “I’m on my way to heaven” — not saying whether it’s via rapture or death.

The meaning of this song, particularly the music video, has been highly debated. However, most can agree there are two different Cudi’s in the video.

   View 1: Mr. Rager is the Cudi in black (the addicted one), and he destroys what’s left of the old Cudi, and the persona of Mr. Rager lives on.

   View 2: Mr. Rager is the Cudi in brown. The building is his body/life, which has been almost destroyed by himself and drugs. Mr. Rager, the addicted Cudi, is attempting to break back into his life again, which the new Cudi (black jacket) has recently regained control of (he was clean of coke when writing Mr. Rager). The people Mr. Rager fights are actually his friends (including Ye at 4:20) who are trying to help him (notice how none of them actually fight back, they just try to restrain him), but Mr. Rager fights against their help (as many drug addicts do). The 1 girl is in fact Jaime and the dust is a simple metaphor for the past (as she left him because of his poor decisions and drug abuse). In the end, only Cudi himself, can vanquish his own addiction and own self (Mr. Rager).

songs.full_title: Erase Me by Kid Cudi (Ft. Kanye West)
songs.title: Erase Me

description.plain:
A break from the perfection of Cudi’s rhythmic wordplay throughout the album, “Erase Me” offers him the chance to be a lounge singer relaying the perils of the “famous rapper.”   Kanye’s interjection of swift dialog and faster paced rapping offers a break from Scott’s more dramatic tone.

The song offers an insight into the women that the rap game brings to the artists.  Even though the women know it’s a “new nightmare” and the artist feels “a bit complete” it is doomed from the start.

songs.full_title: Man on the Moon (The Anthem) by Kid Cudi
songs.title: Man on the Moon (The Anthem)

description.plain:
One of the defining songs of Kid Cudi’s early career, and frequently cited as his best song, the gloomy “Man on the Moon” first introduced Cudi’s notorious ‘Moon Man’ persona to the world. Released in 2008—before his debut album, the breakthrough and the fame—it was featured on Cudi’s first official mixtape A Kid Named Cudi.

The song is primarily about Kid Cudi being different not only in his music, but a different person in life. Kid Cudi’s ‘Man on the Moon’ reference is simply an exaggeration on him being such a different person that he’s out of this world. Hence he is that ‘Man on the Moon.’ Sampling Nosaj Thing’s “Aquarium,” the somber instrumental gives the song a palpably solitary feel.

Cudi would later go on and use the ‘Man on the Moon’ alias for his acclaimed album trilogy: Man on the Moon: The End of Day (2009), on which this song was included as a bonus track, Man on the Moon II: The Legend of Mr. Rager (2010) and Man on the Moon III: The Chosen (2020).

songs.full_title: By Design by Kid Cudi (Ft. André 3000)
songs.title: By Design

description.plain:
“By Design” is the first ever Cudi-André 3000 collaboration and the first of the two André 3K features on Passion, Pain & Demon Slayin'. André is also featured on “The Guide.”

The energetic collab is about going with the universal flow of life, to not think too much and let life work its magic. Both Cudi and André rap about their unique methods and tendencies in music and life. Their differences separate them from their peers, but make their lives much more exciting.

Interestingly, André 3000 is credited by his birth name, “André Benjamin.” He’s similarly credited on “The Guide.”

songs.full_title: Baptized in Fire by Kid Cudi (Ft. Travis Scott)
songs.title: Baptized in Fire

description.plain:
“Baptized In Fire” is the follow up to Cudi and Travis' first collaboration, “through the late night,” from Travis' album Birds In The Trap Sing McKnight (Although Cudi also provided some vocals on “Way Back”). The song was confirmed to be on Cudi’s album Passion, Pain, and Demon Slayin' when he posted a tweet saying Travis was the only feature on the project at the time.

Cudi has been a major influence on Travis, but this is the first time Travis is featured on one of Cudi’s songs.

songs.title: Immortal

description.plain:
The third single from Cudder’s album, INDICUD. It features a sample from MGMT’s “Congratulations” in reverse.

This song is about Cudi’s return of powers not in his music game, but in himself. In multiple INDICUD songs Cudi says “fuck you” to those who think he left the rap game and with it his musical talent. Cudi has faced, overcome, and learned from a lot of challenges in his life. Which can be seen in his past 2 albums and his recent struggles with depression. But Cudi has grown from that pain and gained powers from those experiences, giving him the feeling of immortality.

https://twitter.com/ducidni/status/282917894176796675

songs.title: Rose Golden

description.plain:
On “Rose Golden,” Cudi and Willow Smith speak on being destined for greatness.  Though they have experience obstacles in their life, they have listened to those who believed in them, namely their mother and themselves.

The song carries a theme of independence and faith is oneself.  The duo coin the term “Rose Golden” to represent their combination of love and greatness in all their endeavors.

The rose gold color has also previously appeared on Cudi’s Indicud album artwork.

songs.title: Ghost!

description.plain:
“Ghost!” (sometimes stylized, such as on the Man on the Moon 2 tracklist, in all-caps as “GHOST!”) is about depression. When you’re depressed you become a shadow of your former self. You’re tired all the time, apathetic towards things you once enjoyed, and like a ghost you hover, becoming stagnant and uncertain.

This track samples “My Rainbow Life” by The Freak Scene.

songs.title: Love.

description.plain:
Released to his Soundcloud March 3rd, “Love” marked Cudder’s first offering in quite a while. According to Scott, the song was cut from Satellite Flight.

Produced by Scott and Dot Da Genius (who together make up the musical group WZRD), this beautiful piece showcases a more loving and caring side of Scott. Happy and thankful for the world around him, he is a man who has truly found peace.

songs.title: Tequila Shots

description.plain:
Kid Cudi embarks on the final chapter of the Man on the Moon trilogy by reflecting on past struggles and ongoing internal wars.

Cudi depicts imagery of a storm stirring up within him, but he can’t back down from the fight, despite his fears of crashing. He also mimics Common’s narration as a callback to the first Man on the Moon.

In an interview with Zane Lowe, Cudi expressed that “Tequila Shots” was one of the first tracks he finished for Man on the Moon III—even before he knew he was going to make the album. While discussing the song, he shared:

It sounds like such an introduction, it sounds like you pick right back up where we left off ten years ago.

The production features a high-pitched synth over a pressing bass with a melodic hook reminiscent of his 2009 self, courtesy of friend and producer, Dot Da Genius, and production duo, Take a Daytrip.

In the Making of Man on the Moon III livestream on December 12th, 2020,  Dot Da Genius and Daytrip explained that the song was created in the first time they met Cudi after the release of THE SCOTTS. The song acquired its name “Tequila Shots” because they took tequila shots to celebrate the song’s release.

songs.full_title: Make Her Say (I Poke Her Face) by Kid Cudi (Ft. Common & Kanye West)
songs.title: Make Her Say (I Poke Her Face)
songs.title_with_featured: Make Her Say (I Poke Her Face) (Ft. Common & Kanye West)

description.plain:
Produced by Kanye West, “Make Her Say” was originally to be titled “I Poke Her Face,” but record execs weren’t comfortable with such a lewd title. Odd, considering the entire song is about how excellent fellatio is.

The track first appeared on the 2009 release Dat Kid From Cleveland and then later that year on his debut studio album, Man On The Moon: The End Of The Day.

The song extensively samples an acoustic version of Lady Gaga’s “Poker Face.”

songs.title: Solo Dolo (Nightmare)

description.plain:
“Solo Dolo” focuses primarily on Cudi’s lonely feelings in the world and how he escapes reality through his dreams, which is one of the primary themes of the album.

The haunting melody is sampled from “The Traitor” by the Menahan Street Band. This is the beginning of Act II: Rise of the Night Terrors.

Cudi would go on to produce a Part II to “Solo Dolo” for his 2013 album Indicud, with a feature from Kendrick Lamar.

songs.title: Girls

description.plain:
8th track off Kid Cudi’s 4th solo album, “Indicud”. The hook samples “Kids At Whitney High” from the movie The Ringer

Kid Cudi has many anthems, this is a single man’s anthem. Throughout the song he describes his single life and the perks and fun that come with it.

He didn’t title the song “pretty girls” “foreign girls”, “fat girls”, “skinny girls”, “white girls” or “black girls” JUST “girls”. This serves in some parts to emphasize his love of all types of women, no matter how they are made up on the outside. In short, Cudi uses this title to show how he doesn’t give a fuck about what’s on the outside, he loves it all.

songs.title: Frequency

description.plain:
After spending time experimenting with different production and sounds on the albums and tracks released prior to this song, Cudders re-teamed with producer Plain Pat on “Frequency” to deliver a track that is more reminiscent of the familiar raps & croons found on Cudi’s first three albums, A KiD Named CuDi and Man on the Moon: I & II.

“Frequency” is Cudi’s first release after his 4th studio album Speedin' Bullet To Heaven, which was released in December of 2015.  This also signified a change in style for Cudi, moving from the gritty punk rock sound of Speedin' to the rapping and sensual humming style found on this track.

songs.full_title: Too Bad I Have to Destroy You Now by Kid Cudi
songs.title: Too Bad I Have to Destroy You Now
songs.title_with_featured: Too Bad I Have to Destroy You Now

description.plain:
Many of Cudi’s early releases relied heavily on him rapping. Lately, however, he seems to have drifted from this straight-rap style, instead blending in experimental melodies and unique instrumentals. On “Too Bad I Have To Destroy You Now,” however, rapper-Cud reemerges in a BIG way. He explained this reemergence in an interview with Complex.

This was actually written by Cudi 2 or 3 years ago when he was starting to break through his personal problems and come into his own.

I have a bunch of powers but unfortunately I cannot write raps unless I’m ultimately fueled to write a rap, and it happens every so often. When it does happen it happens in the way of a “Too Bad I Have To Destroy You Now.” Where I’ve been waiting to unleash and I finally have and even though you haven’t heard many raps from me, it’s just enough to have you satisfied. Also, I aim for timeless. That’s always a goal.

songs.full_title: Surfin' by Kid Cudi (Ft. Pharrell Williams)
songs.title: Surfin’

description.plain:
“Surfin'” is a celebratory anthem that finishes off Passion, Pain & Demon Slaying on a high note. While proclaiming his success as a trailblazer, Cudi takes aim at the industry and the biters within music.

“Waves” is used as a metaphor for the type of sound or style an artist has. Cudi’s been a huge influence in pioneering the new, softer side of hip hop, thanks to albums like Man on the Moon: The End of Day—thus making his own waves.

Cudi premiered “Surfin'” at Trillectro in August of 2016, but wasn’t officially released as the second single for Passion, Pain & Demon Slaying until September 30, 2016.

songs.title: Unfuckwittable

description.plain:
Second track (and first song) on Kid Cudi’s third studio album, Indicud. Elements of his alternative project WZRD run throughout this song, with Cudi jamming the electric guitar.

“Unfuckwittable”, produced only by Cudi himself, brings many positive vibes and feelings of empowerment Cudi promised with this album. The main message is similar to that of “Immortal”: he’s invincible and no one can bring him down. “Don’t you feel it?”

songs.title: All Along

description.plain:
The 15th track on Man on the Moon II: The Legend of Mr. Rager.

Cudi realizes that he will forever be alone in some way and that he has to fight on his own the battles life throws at him. It’s a sad song, but it’s consoling at the same time.

Actually, “All Along” was meant to be the last track on the album, but Cudi then recorded three more songs: “Don’t Play This Song”, “Ghost!”, and “Trapped In My Mind”. He felt like these songs made a better conclusion of the story and that “All Along” would have been “a very sad song to end an album”.

songs.full_title: Young Lady by Kid Cudi (Ft. Father John Misty)
songs.title: Young Lady

description.plain:
Cudder switches things up here, collaborating with amazing folk singer Father John Misty. As with the rest of the songs on Indicud, this was personally produced by Scott himself, here using a sample from Father John Misty’s track “Hollywood Forever Cemetery Sings”.

The song focuses on a mysterious young girl, which led to great speculation among listeners, but was later revealed, suprisingly, to be Emma Watson.

https://twitter.com/KidCudi/status/666555892578385921

Misty explained how this came about in an interview:

We didn’t converse much. He heard my music in a vintage boutique store in Hollywood that a friend of mine [owns]. She was playing the album in the store and he asked her what it was. She told him and he ended up sampling it and then I got an email from his management. But I did go into the studio with him for a day, put down some backing vocals, and we just kind of tripped out.

songs.full_title: Trapped in My Mind by Kid Cudi
songs.title: Trapped in My Mind

description.plain: The last song on KiD Cudi’s sophomore album Man on the Moon II: The Legend of Mr. Rager. A final culmination of the rager’s story  where he finds himself trapped in his mind with an inevitability and acceptance of staying there forever.  By doing this his past, which keeps him confined, can be acknowledged and used to learn. Instead of moving forward and trying to forget this dark past, he’s accepting it.

songs.title: Dat New “New”

description.plain:
Produced by Dot Da Genius in 2008, “Dat New New” was a single that was eventually featured on some of Cudi’s mixtapes.

The meaning of what “Dat New New” is is highly debated by fans. It could be boasting his self made fame by referring to a strain of weed only Cudi has because he has the wealth and status to get stuff like that. “Dat new new” could also refer to his lyrics and songs in general, always being fresh, original, and “hot shit”.

songs.title: The Void

description.plain:
On “The Void,” Cudi details his struggles with mental health, describing how he will do anything to avoid succumbing to depression. He also takes a moment to thank his fans for supporting him through the years and sticking along for the ride.

In a Twitch livestream discussing the album’s creation, Dot Da Genius revealed that the beat and hook of the song were created during the Indicud sessions back in 2013. The instrumental samples 2011’s “Time” by Pachanga Boys.

songs.title: Mad Solar

description.plain:
The 11th Track on the Indicud album.

  Kid Cudi has been known for his association with outer space, specifically the moon. It symbolizes many things including being high, his other-worldly thoughts and place, but it also symbolized the loneliness and darkness in his life. One could say he was “lunar”. This was seen throughout MOTMI and MOTMII (just to name a few: Solo Dolo, Man on the Moon, Soundtrack 2 My Life, All Along, Ghost, Mr. Rager).

  This represents a transition. He’s still Cudi, but he’s reached a new persona and place in life. He’s in a happier, more content, more independent and unfuckwittable place (this can be seen in his most recent interview with Complex Magazine). He still carries and personifies the ideas associated with space, but has a new dimension to it. A brighter one. A solar one

songs.title: Kitchen

description.plain:
“Kitchen” is a song about the difficulty of finding somebody and ‘laying low.’ Cudi reassures the subject by telling her that he’s “one strong lover.” The song is lyrically repetitive, layering the repeated refrain and hook over flourishing strings and drums.

“Kitchen” is the last song of PP&DS’s third act, titled ‘Act III: Niveaux de l'Amour.’ This translates to ‘Act III: Levels of Love.’

It’s produced by Plain Pat and Dot Da Genius, the latter of whom previously collaborated with Cudi as one-half of their indie-rock group, WZRD.

Kid Cudi later thanked Jaden Smith for background vocals on this song:

https://twitter.com/KidCudi/status/811001747619475457?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw

Kid Cudi performed this song live on The Tonight Show on February 8, 2017.

https://youtu.be/S_nDNzlOW24

songs.full_title: She Knows This by Kid Cudi
songs.title: She Knows This

description.plain:
“She Knows This” revisits the theme of Cudi’s trippy, occasionally superfluous, sexual parties.  A lover at heart, Cudi’s focus on his female counterparts is reflected not only in the title of the song, but also repeated throughout the chorus and described in the verses.

The track is produced as expected by Dot Da Genius, but is also accompanied in production by J Gramm and FnZ.

The song also served as the title song for the first part of Cudi’s Artist Spotlight Series, titled “She Knows This – The Rager, The Menace”.  This lyric of “the rager, the menace” first appeared in Cudi’s 2010 track from MOTMII “These Worries (feat. Mary J Blige)”.

songs.title: Another Day

description.plain:
“Another Day,” the third track on Act I: Return 2 Madness, recalls Kid Cudi’s reckless party nights. In an attempt to numb the “same old pain,” he surrounds himself with women, alcohol, and drugs. This Cudi is dangerously reminiscent of the Cudi from Man on the Moon II: he is back to raging.

Kid Cudi raps about the adventures of Mr. Rager, but at the end of the track he seems to awaken from a night of partying with a desire to make a change in his life. He closes the song with a reference to his past life as Mr. Rager, hinting that he is taking his life in a different direction.

The track once again features production from Dot Da Genius and Take a Daytrip, with assistance from Nosaj Thing. Kid Cudi has sampled Nosaj Thing before; his 2006 track, “Aquarium,” was used as the instrumental for Cudi’s July 2008 single, “Man on the Moon.”

songs.full_title: MANIAC by Kid Cudi (Ft. Cage & St. Vincent)
songs.title: MANIAC

description.plain:
“MANIAC” marks the first song in “The Transformation” section of MOTMII. It begins Cudi’s exploration of the darker parts of his personality. Breaking convention, Cudi admits that he’s embraced these aspects of his personality, often choosing seclusion over displaying his true feelings since it’s less difficult to deal with than the real world. It is also argued that this is the first song written after beginning withdrawal from coke.

On October 31st (Halloween) a short movie called “Maniac” with Kid Cudi and Cage acting as serial killers was released. It is not the music video of the song but used themes of it and features new music:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=FVemNLOwCJ0

songs.full_title: Mr. Solo Dolo III by Kid Cudi
songs.title: Mr. Solo Dolo III

description.plain:
On “Mr. Solo Dolo III,” Cudi delves into his addiction and struggles stemming from his isolation. Throughout his career, Cudi has been well-known as a pioneer of openness and honesty related to struggles with mental health in hip-hop, a genre that has typically bolstered the male image of high levels of confidence and no invulnerabilities to remark.

The third track of the trilogy reiterates the feelings of loneliness Cudi has felt throughout his life, which define his musical style, career, and the theme of the Man on the Moon trilogy.
